children.text: Content Standard 1: Students shall apply the essential skills and techniques to perform music.
Demonstrate characteristic tone quality in practical registers using moderate dynamic levels
Demonstrate accurate intonation (e.g., tubing length, alternate fingerings, individual instruments, instrumental pitch tendencies, chords)

Demonstrate vertical alignment within an ensemble
  • internalizing beat
  • following conductor (e.g., preparatory beat, tempo changes, meter)
  • varied meters (e.g., simple, compound, asymmetrical)
  • rhythmic patterns (e.g., dotted eighth and sixteenth notes, syncopation, triplets)
  • meter changes (e.g., to )
Perform scales by memory (e.g., major, minor, chromatic)
Perform rudiments by memory (e.g., single stroke roll, long roll, five stroke roll, seven stroke roll, nine stroke roll, flam, paradiddle)
Perform instrument-specific technique builders (e.g., lip slurs for brass, arpeggios, thirds, etudes, chorales, tonguing and slurring patterns, double stops for percussion, octaves)
Sight-read simple music literature
Content Standard 2: Students shall demonstrate creative expression through music.
Perform music of contrasting styles (e.g., marches, suites, overtures, Baroque, Romantic, Classical)
Improvise simple rhythmic and melodic variations in a specific style and meter
Perform to achieve a characteristic ensemble sound (e.g., blend, balance, intonation)

Perform fundamental elements and principles of phrasing and expression
  • tempi (e.g., grave, lento, andante, moderato, allegro, presto)
  • expressive markings (e.g., cantabile, dolce, grandioso, maestoso)
  • articulations (e.g., tenuto, staccato, legato, accents, marcato)
  • dynamics [e.g., crescendo, decrescendo, pianissimo (pp), piano (p), mezzo piano (mp), mezzo forte (mf), forte (f), fortissimo (ff)]
Content Standard 3: Students shall listen to, describe, analyze, perform, and evaluate music.
Identify examples of a varied repertoire of music (e.g., classical, pop, jazz, marches)
Demonstrate understanding of music notation and symbols by reading and performing music
Develop criteria for evaluating individual and group musical performances
Evaluate a performance, arrangement, or improvisation by comparing it to exemplary models
Exhibit proper etiquette in rehearsal, performances, and audience settings
Content Standard 4: Students shall make connections between music and other disciplines.
Describe characteristics (e.g., setting, plot, historical significance) of program music (e.g., Peter and the Wolf, The Tempest, The Great Locomotive Chase, The Light in the Window)
Identify the role and function of instrumental music in lifelong learning
Identify musical traditions from a variety of cultures
Identify musical traditions that relate to other arts and other disciplines (e.g., Baroque, Romantic, non-Western)
Describe cultural and technological influences on music (e.g., software, hardware, recording, Web 2.0)
Demonstrate espirit de corps
